an9.38:4.1: Then two brahmin cosmologists went up to the Buddha,
an9.38:4.3: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side
an9.38:5.1: “Master Gotama, Pūraṇa Kassapa claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
an9.38:5.2: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
an9.38:5.4: ‘With infinite knowledge I know and see that the world is infinite.’
an9.38:5.5: And the Jain leader Nāṭaputta also claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
an9.38:5.6: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
an9.38:5.8: ‘With infinite knowledge I know and see that the world is finite.’
an9.38:5.9: These two claim to speak from knowledge, but they directly contradict each other. Which one of them speaks the truth, and which falsehood?”
an9.38:6.3: ‘These two claim to speak from knowledge, but they directly contradict each other. Which one of them speaks the truth, and which falsehood?’
an9.38:6.4: I will teach you the Dhamma. Listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
an9.38:7.1: “Suppose there were four men standing in the four directions. Each of them was extremely fast, with an extremely mighty stride.
an9.38:7.2: They’re as fast as a light arrow easily shot across the shadow of a palm tree by a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow.
an9.38:7.3: Their stride was such that it spanned from the eastern ocean to the western ocean. Then the man standing in the east would say:
an9.38:7.4: ‘I will reach the end of the world by travelling.’
an9.38:7.5: Though he’d travel for his whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—he’d die along the way, never reaching the end of the world.
an9.38:7.6: Then the man standing in the west …
an9.38:7.7: Then the man standing in the north …
an9.38:7.8: Then the man standing in the south would say:
an9.38:7.9: ‘I will reach the end of the world by travelling.’
an9.38:7.10: Though he’d travel for his whole lifespan of a hundred years—pausing only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness—he’d die along the way, never reaching the end of the world.
an9.38:7.12: I say it’s not possible to know or see or reach the end of the world by running like this.
an9.38:7.13: But I also say there’s no making an end of suffering without reaching the end of the world.

an9.38:9.1: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
an9.38:9.2: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world.
an9.38:9.4: ‘They’re included in the world, and haven’t yet left the world.’

an9.38:13.1: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
an9.38:13.2: This is called a mendicant who, having gone to the end of the world, meditates at the end of the world. And they’ve crossed over clinging to the world.”
